data.title: Fix for issue #1257
data.body:
Fixes #1257

The editor didn't test that a mission area actually existed, so when you switched to the editor, it would trigger the crash.

It now tests if there is a mission area when switching to the editor tool, and if there is not, prompts for the creation of a new one, similar to the auto-prompt for creating terrain blocks.

data.title: Player & setSequenceGroundSpeed
Fixes issue #1277

milestone.description: This version will focus on processing two of the major outstanding pull requests, James Urquhart's [TorqueScript interpreter improvements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/81) and Tim Condon's [GUI additions](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/545). Along with that we'll be bringing in lots of other TS-related enhancements, adding unit tests for TS to make sure we don't break your games, and processing even more of the outstanding issue list.

data.title: Connecting to dedicated server causes crash
data.body:
I compiled and started a linux dedicated server and then tried to connect to it, but this caused a crash on the client. The crash happens when I try to connect from linux to a linux dedicated but also when I try to connect to it from windows. Starting the windows binary as dedicated server did also not work.

Another issue is the dedicated server does not get listed with the master server, but this may be an issue of my master server.

data.title: Linux dedicated server segfault issue
data.body:
If you build linux dedicated server and launch it you will get a segfault error with the message:

Format GFXFormatB8G8R8A8 not supported with specified profile.
% Segfault

/Engine/source/terrain/terrRender.cpp(120,0): {Fatal} - TerrainBlock::_updateLayerTexture - The texture size doesn't match the requested size!

Looks like someone edited the terrain renderer without considering/testing the dedicated built.

PS: I run Opensuse

data.title: Linux FileDialog does not work in 3.7 current
data.body:
FileDialog does not currently work for linux, as the execute function for the linux platform code just returns false. 

Needs to get an implementation so stuff can be saved through the editor.

data.title: Fixed Function Pipeline needs removing
data.body:
When working on the oculus stuff with stock T3D development, I noticed a rather bizarre rendering bug. The problem was the first thing I rendered after the oculus display (which uses its own rendering code with the same D3D9 device) didn't get rendered, despite resetting the rendering state with:

```
GFX->disableShaders();
GFX->updateStates(true);
```

After 3 hours I discovered to my horror that in GFXD3D9Device::setupGenericShaders the fixed function pipeline is used for GUI rendering which meant the shaders never got disabled since the engine thought the shader was still 0x0.

It's 2015. Why on earth does stock T3D still have a fixed function rendering pipeline fallback?

data.title: No OpenAL output in Debian Wheezy
data.body:
Reposted as requested:

It builds! It runs! However, there is no sound on Debian Wheezy. During startup, I see this in the console:

SFXSystem::createDevice - created OpenAL device 'OpenAL Soft'
Provider: OpenAL
Device: OpenAL Soft
Hardware: No
Buffers: 16

I hear a brief crackle as this scrolls by, but when playing the demo maps, there is no sound at all. It was just now suggested to me to try FMOD instead.

data.title: WheeledVehicle not effected by Physical Zones
data.body:
Found in T3D MIT V3.6.1

Flying vehicles and players are effected by PhysicalZones.
Wheeled vehicles are not - not by velocity, gravity, or applied force.
HoverVehicles i don't know about.

Proven with these values:

Physical Zone Properties in Question:
velocityMod 1
GravityMod (tried 0 and -2)
AppliedForce ( 0 -20000 0)

WheeledVehicle properties in question:
Mass 600
Drag 0.6
Density 4

haven't tried with other values, but with -2 gravity and 20000 push force the vehicle should at least shake, no?

data.title: Compilation error on Debian 8, Release builds
data.body:
I have installed all required dependencies. Operating system is Debian 8 (testing/jessie) 64-bit, Torque3D Git is up-to-date. This is a `Release` build by the way. **`Debug` builds properly.**

This is the output of `make` (using CMake):

```
[  1%] Built target convexDecomp
[  1%] Built target libogg
[  2%] Built target libvorbis

[ 19%] Built target lungif
[ 22%] Built target ljpeg
[ 23%] Built target lpng
[ 24%] Built target squish
[ 27%] Built target opcode
[ 42%] Built target collada
[ 43%] Built target pcre

accumulationVolume.cpp:(.text+0x1831): undefined reference to `ScenePolyhedralObject<SceneSpace, PolyhedronImpl<PolyhedronVectorData> >::initPersistFields()'
CMakeFiles/Full.dir/__/__/Engine/source/T3D/accumulationVolume.cpp.o: In function `ConcreteClassRep<AccumulationVolume>::init()':
accumulationVolume.cpp:(.text._ZN16ConcreteClassRepI18AccumulationVolumeE4initEv[_ZN16ConcreteClassRepI18AccumulationVolumeE4initEv]+0x4d): undefined reference to `ScenePolyhedralObject<SceneSpace, PolyhedronImpl<PolyhedronVectorData> >::initPersistFields()'
CMakeFiles/Full.dir/__/__/Engine/source/T3D/occlusionVolume.cpp.o: In function `ConcreteClassRep<OcclusionVolume>::init()':
occlusionVolume.cpp:(.text._ZN16ConcreteClassRepI15OcclusionVolumeE4initEv[_ZN16ConcreteClassRepI15OcclusionVolumeE4initEv]+0x1f): undefined reference to `ScenePolyhedralObject<SceneSpace, PolyhedronImpl<PolyhedronVectorData> >::initPersistFields()'
```
